# Introduction

## Moving averages

###  Introduction

\highlight{Moving averages} (or \highlight{linear filters}) are ubiquitous in trend-cycle extraction and seasonal adjustment (e.g. : X-12-ARIMA):
$$
M_\theta(X_t)=\sum_{k=-p}^{+f}\theta_kX_{t+k}
$$


\pause \bigskip

\faArrowCircleRight{} In general, \highlight{symmetric} moving averages ($p=f$ et $\theta_{-i}=\theta_i$) 

\bigskip

\faArrowCircleRight{} For \highlightbf{real-time estimates}, we must rely on \highlight{asymmetric} filters: revisions and delay in turning points detections

# Methods
# Multiple methods for trend-cycle estimation

###  Comparison of five methods

- Local polynomial filters by @proietti2008

  * Direct asymmetric filter (\highlightbf{DAF}): local polynomial of degree 3 (as for symmetric filters) \faArrowCircleRight{} used in STL
  
  * Linear-Constant (\highlightbf{LC}) filter: trend is of degree 1 and asymmetric filter preserves of degree 0 (constant) \faArrowCircleRight{} Musgrave filters
  
  * Quadratic-Linear (\highlightbf{QL}) filter: trend is of degree 2 and asymmetric filter preserves trends of degree 1
  
\pause
- Fidelity-Smoothness-Timeliness (\highlightbf{FST}) minimization approach of @ch15HBSA \faArrowCircleRight{} FST = filter that preserves linear trends and minimizes the Timeliness

\pause
 \faArrowCircleRight{} Methods implemented in the \faIcon{r-project} package `rjdfilters` available at \href{https://github.com/palatej/rjdfilters}{\faGithub{} palatej/rjdfilters}  

\pause
- Filters based on Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Space (RKHS) methodology by @dagumbianconcini2008 
\faArrowCircleRight{} $b_{q,\phi}$ = filters with a "bandwidth" that minimizes phase shift.

# Conclusion


### Conclusion and improvements

- Different methods can lead to very different trend-cycle estimates

- \bcattention Seasonal adjustment process already uses asymmetric filters: methods should also be compared in the seasonal adjustment process.

- \bclampe More series should be studied and more investigations on the different parameters (especially with FST)

- \bcattention Outliers impact on exctraction methods: during the COVID-19 crisis several AO \faArrowCircleRight{} study of asymmetric filters based on robust methods \bclampe
